content.description:
Best power endurance boulder in the canyon. Start seated on DVD, climb that problem from right to left, then continue through the base of Ping and I Am Sam. Then continue through the v8/9 Lurp Sit problem (crux, and has more hard moves than when you traverse in from the right rather than starting seated), and then continue through this onto the slabs. Hold it together on the slabs until you hit the arete on the far left end, then top out.

Variations of this line include finishing around the corner, or on the heinous blank slab between powderbird and the left arete.
content.protection: Nice to have a bunch of pads, but you'd need a shirtless beanie army to pad the whole thing.
content.location: Traverses all the way from the right of DVD to the left arete of the west face.

content.description: Climb the crack in the middle of the west face of the Sam Trap boulder.
content.location: Middle of the west face of the Sam Trap boulder.

content.description: Climbs edges on the face to the left of the crack feature
content.location: Just left of Snowbird Crack on the west side of the Sam Trap boulder

content.description:
The best line on the boulder. Start on the white, low rounded hold, with a couple options for feet. Make a big move up left and another right. Then do one of the stranger moves around, and use the iron dyke to get better established on the wall. Then finish up and right.

Aesthetic, fun, and a little spicy.

For a little more power endurance, consider adding Dick Van Dyke onto the start of this. I've heard it's in the v10 range for that linkup, and that seems about right.
content.protection: 3 pads would be best. Make sure to pad to the right, where it's possible to take a big swinging fall.
content.location: The most obvious problem on this boulder. It is on the left face of the boulder, around the corner from DVD, where DVD ends on the big white sloper jug. Finish straight up.

content.description:
Super fun movement on edges low on the wall. Find a small roof with two cool crimps underneath, throw a foot on, and make your way up and left with a couple of amazing deadpoints. A bit of a dirtburgler, but it's got fantastic movement, and solid rock.

Finish straight up the wall, or I'd say finish wherever. Once you are at the 10 foot mark, it's all around the same difficulty to top out.
content.protection: 2 pads covers the landing, but you could just use 1 to cover the crux and be safe
content.location: This line sits down and right of the big crack system in the middle of the large, uphill face of the boulder.

content.description: Climb the face just right of the prominent crack feature. Moves up and then angles a bit to the right. The crack features are within reach, and it's a bit hard to know exactly which ones are on vs off, so just use what feels right to you.
content.location: Fourth route to the left of Dick Van Dyke, and just right of the prominent crack feature. The ground steps up a few feet just left of where you start this route

content.description: This climb starts on some right-facing holds on the seemingly blank face in between Fakie and Powderbird and avoids the arete. Use some mantles/thumb presses and your choice of sloper-crimps to make the crux move to the sloper jug at the lip. Alternatively, once you hit a right hand tooth a couple feet from the top, you can traverse left and into the arete and top out on Fakie, although it is a bit easier and less heady. Not sure which was the original route
content.location: The slab in between Fakie and Powderbird. BB doesn't describe start holds

content.description: Start low on good edges to the left of the jug feature. Move to the jug, up through kneebar and undercling with the left, and then finish with some reachy moves to some rails and then the top.
content.location: Third route left of Dick Van Dyke, on the west facing side of the boulder. Looks for the good jug at about chest height.

content.description: Tucked back behind Dick Van Dyke, this boulder is dusty, but worth a visit. There are a ton of holds, but most of them are bad. Try to just use the good ones.
content.location: Start on the left side, near the aspen, seated, on the bigger hold. Cleverly place feet and drive up and right, then hatch through the hole above and top out.

content.description: This climb shares the same start as Fakie, however stays left of the arete and climbs the face. There are a few good holds with an easy top out. This route has a safer landing than some of the other routes on the boulder, and is optimal for a good warm up!
content.location: The face left of "Fakie" using the same start hold.

content.description: Starts on good low edges on the left side of the northwest corner of the Sam Trap boulder.  Head straight up the arete.
content.location: Arete on the northwest corner of the Sam Trap boulder.

content.description:
Awesome climbing on great rock, and such a stunning, obvious line that flows really well. Start on Dick Van Dyke, climb across to the base of Ping, chill for a bit on the rounded good holds down there, then do the crux moves of Ping, finishing as per that problem.

It's hard to find a better power endurance boulder around than this line! Visually striking and climbs extraordinarily well.
content.protection: You'll want a few pads, I think, especially for the crux up on Ping, which can result in a wild swing to the left.
content.location: Link from Dick Van Dyke, starting on the right side, all the way to the left, then finish on Ping.

content.description:
Among the more contrived boulders around, this link is still great fun.

I don't know how many people have climbed this. The grade floated by others has been v10. In my opinion, it's not as hard as the Wheel of Snowbird, but harder than DVD to Ping.

I've heard a couple different names for this, but sounds like Aller Retour is the official one.

For bonus climbing, finish on Backstroke, v4.
content.protection: 8 pads or so covers it? but i generally use 1-2
content.location: Start on the jugs of Dick Van Dyke, climb to the Ping start jug, and then reverse the traverse back to the start jugs of DVD.

content.description: Start Sitting on jugs just right of the large flat overhang. Traverse left on the dike feature under the roof. Finish around the corner on jugs.
content.protection: A few pads are helpful, or you can have your spotter drag the pad along beneath you.
content.location: As you approach the Sam Trap boulder, the first feature you will see is a low roof at about chest height. Dick Van Dyke is under this roof.

content.description:
Amazing problem on edges up a committing face with a downsloping landing. You're not likely to get dead on a fall from the top, but injury likelihood is pretty high unless you have a big mess of pads and a good spotter.

At my height, this problem involves a big jump off the ground and grabbing two edges high on the face, then powering up through a couple of other holds to the top with marginal feet. Pretty spectacular.
content.protection: 3+ pads if you can get em
content.location: On the big overhanging face around the corner right of Ping. Above the left side of the Dick Van Dyke traverse. Edges that you start on are at about 9 feet.

content.description: Start sitting on the jugs on the right side of the low roof. A long move to a gaston out left. Finish straight up in the corner after the shelf. Drape bouldering pad over the boulder just behind/below your back.
content.location: Just right of Dick Van Dyke
